sect1.title: Requirements
sect1.para: Bugle is intended to work on any POSIX-compliant operating system that use the X Windowing System, dynamic linking, and LD_PRELOAD for library interposition. If it fails to work on such an operating system, please let me know (I only use it on GNU/Linux). Windows and Mac OSX are not currently supported as they are not based on X.
The following packages are required to compile Bugle:

listitem.para: GCC, at least version 3.2, and not 4.0 (see the FAQ for an explanation of why).
OpenGL header files, including a recent version of glext.h (older versions should work, but it will be difficult to debug any code that uses newer features).
GLEW: 1.4.0 has been tested, but older versions may work

sect1.title: Configuring
sect1.para: Bugle uses the standard configure command for compile-time configuration. Generic instructions may be found in INSTALL in the root of the source directory. In general, configure will auto-detect optional packages and use them only if present, but you can also prevent it from depending on certain packages with the following flags:

Bugle does not use threads itself, but applications that it debugs might, and bugle needs to use appropriate locking and thread-local storage libraries. The correct option should be auto-detected, but you can force it with --with-threads=model. Valid models are pthreads and single (i.e., no threads).

Finally, bugle intercepts events from X11. While there are no known cases of this causing problems, it is difficult to make the interception completely transparent, and so the --disable-xevent option is available to disable it at compile time.

sect1.title: Compiling and installing
sect1.para: Compilation is as simple as running make. Before installing, you should remove any previous installation of bugle to avoid leaving old versions of files around. If you do not have your original installation tree to run make uninstall, you should at least remove the files in /usr/local/lib/bugle and /usr/local/lib/libbugle*. To install the new version, run make install as root.
Next, you need to install some files for the user that will run bugle. Create a directory $HOME/.bugle, and copy doc/examples/filters and doc/examples/statistics into it.

sect1.title: Compiling on Windows
sect1.para: Installing from source on Windows is supported, but it is significantly trickier than on UNIX-like systems, and currently only recommended for experts. The intended target is MinGW; you can try using Cygwin as well, but it is not tested.

Apart from the core of MinGW, you will need to install MSYS, Perl, regex (user-contributed version), and msysDTK. If you install GTK+ and GtkGLExt, you need to ensure that pkg-config knows where to find them (setting PKG_CONFIG_PATH appropriately). If you install GLEW, you need to ensure that the compiler and linker can find it (setting CPATH and LIBRARY_PATH appropriately).
